title: @Riot can I get a rioter to answer these questions?
body:
Last season you had a clear goal, strategic diversity. What is the goal this season?
What are you trying to do with the game this season and why?
Are you happy with the current state of the game?
What do you think of the negative stance the boards seem to have taken to the current meta?
Apart from mages are there any other groups that you think need a rejuvenation?

Last and more personally, do you have any plans on modernizing champions like Jayce who do not benefit from as many items as they once did due to there skills not applying on hit affects or not criting? 

Up vote this if you want to see Riot answer these too. Also post your own questions, I want to see what else the community is wanting to know.

replies.body:
Lot of questions here so please forgive some shorter answers:

Significant differences between the different champions in a class has been our biggest focus so far this season, with the changes to marksmen to give them noticeably more different kits being the clearest example of that. We'll be continuing to work on that throughout the year, though will likely introduce some other focuses as well at some point.

We're fairly happy with the state of the game overall, especially as we start to smooth out some of the rough points from the preseason (we're starting to get masteries to a point of decent variety for example). Plenty that still needs work though, from individual champion balance (GP, Ryze, Udyr etc), to systemic game issues (low interaction strategies in top tier play early game, low significance of Rift Herald, player frustration with available options versus stealth champs etc). 

Boards skews pretty negative, compared to discussions on the Devcorner, results from in game surveys, discussions on third party sites like Reddit etc. That's been true historically too, though I'd agree it does feel like a more negative tone at present than usual. There's still some really great feedback and discussion here that illuminates things some of the playerbase are unhappy with. There are also a lot of posts that aren't constructive though which doesn't make for a great signal to noise ratio.  

We're planning on tackling another class in an update at the end of the year. Assassins, initiating tanks and diving fighters are the groups we're considering. We'll potentially work on one or both of those other groups next year, though will reassess closer to the time of course. 

Making sure champions have kits that support an appropriate range of itemization is something we'll continue to work on. Not sure about Jayce specifically though sorry.

I was watching Anklespankin earlier today, and he had a Vayne on his team, and it was impressive to watch his Vayne obliterate people and take almost no damage.

Haters gonna hate :P

Consider this. Vayne gives up quite a bit in terms of raw power when this is involved in her kit. For every instance of an advantage, something is compromised to make the champion, in a sense, non-overbearing. Vayne gets a lot of damage off of the W proc yes, but she can't distribute procs evenly like Gnar can; she loses all procs on a target if she switches, and the vast majority of her damage comes from simple physical damage. Only about 1/5 to maybe 1/4 comes from the true damage procs. So statistically, a lot of her damage is not linked to the W. Sure it hurts like hell, but it takes time to proc that, which you tend to not have a lot of when getting dove in full 5 vs 5 team fights. In smaller fights (2 vs 2 or 3 vs 2) Vayne have more time because less people are going to be attacking her, so she can get more procs off. That's more the area where Vayne is quite strong than full 5 vs. 5 fights. The reason I say this is because of how the champion is built.

Her passive gives bonus movespeed, sure, but it only works when chasing or moving towards enemies, never for running away. That movespeed is significant for clean up and chasing down stragglers, but it gives her nothing for getting away.

Vayne has a very short range Q dash (300 units, compared to 425 for Lucian E and Graves E or 600 on Corki W [1800 when the package is avaliable]) with a low cooldown that functions as an AA reset; fundamentally, this functions in no way as an escape, only an engage and a dodge. Sure you can tumble through a few walls, but your room for error is quite small, and in a full fight that room for error goes down a lot due to stress and the chaos of the fight.

Her E is nothing more than a push-back (470 units back), which is on quite a decent cooldown, even late game. This is primarily because she won't be leveling it except as her last maxing, which means that cooldown stays at 20 until she is at level 14 (CDR from items non-withstanding for the sake of avoiding build issues). With this in mind, other champions with dashes or blinks or hooks or MS buffs (Lucian, Graves, Irelia, Ekko, Tryndamere, Thresh, Nautilus, Leona, Garen, Nidalee, Kennen, Maokai, Zed is debatable but unlikely due to his W's duration counting with his cooldown, the list goes on) will have theirs up before Vayne's E is off of CD. The biggest thing it gives her is the stun if she land it, but that requires at least decent positioning by the Vayne, which is a 2-way interaction between her and the enemy champion; by that I mean you will never get pinned if you keep good positioning vs. a Vayne. Period.

Her ult gives her invisibility on her Q for 1 s, but pinks and Oracle's help to deal with that. In addition, the functionality of her Q doesn't change; it is still a short range repositioning dash and AA reset. Her ult also gives more chase potential but again, no getaway at all except for a 1 s invisibility. Even then, that won't make up for its short range. Part of the biggest reasons why Vayne can win fights is because she gets a reset along with the invisibility that negates damage on her for 1 second, unless she is caught in AOE or skill-shots (cough, cough).

Ultimately, Vayne's true damage is decent, but it doesn't make up even a third of the damage she deals in the average game. In addition, she has no escapes whatsoever, only engage tools. When she commits, she has to commit.
Biggest way to kill a Vayne is single-targeted CC (Lissandra, Maokai, Nautilus, Leona [her Q], Taric, Ryze, Alistar (once the combo is updated and it becomes much harder to mess up [hopefully] etc.). If a Vayne gets hit by any of these in a full fight where the team plays well, then she has no chance (QSS not withstanding, but QSS has a cooldown as well).

Just my thoughts. Hopefully that is sort of clear and concise to give another aspect of the discussion.

Do you think Deathcap warps AP item choices because of how much more overall AP you get when you include in a build? I think its a problem because it creates a lock-in effect for AP champions that simply want a very high ap number inorder to provide hard scaling for their abilites, and less about the strategic reason why you would buy a Deathcap in the first place.

Back then when Hourglass, Rylai's, Luden's and Lichblade were 3000 gold, this was a good balance between the items because its more about which AP item you want that will give a particular effect for your current needs rather than gold efficiency and/or power spikes. With Hourglass and Deathcap being much higher in cost compared to the other AP items, it completely shifts to the idea of simply saving all the gold required to get these two tickets items rather than opting for a strategic reason why you would want a certain AP item.

Would it be better to bring Hourglass's cost in line with other AP items, but reduce the AP? Even changing the ingredients would be needed, i.e. Blasting wand instead of NLR. So you get the following:
{{item:3191}} (1200g)  + {{item:1026}} (850g)  + Combine Cost (1150g) = {{item:3157}} (3200g)

That way, there isn't that big cost saveup and puts the item more about the active instead of its stats.

Honestly, I think I would be much happier with stronger towers.  Right now, its extremely easy to have the jungler gank top lane, get the turret to half HP, then gank again 3 minutes later and get a 10 minute tower.  Most recently I played a game as VI jungle, feel free to check my op.gg, and we had a lux who pushed her tower into this teemo.  With 1 wave of minions, I was able to get the tower down from half HP without taking a single turret shot.  Later on in the game, I took the bot Tier 2 tower from full HP to nothing while only losing half my health in the process.  This was just with {{item:1400}} and {{item:3078}} .  To me that seems to be a big problem.

I'm actually fine with death timers the way they are currently, the problem is there are way too many objectives that you can take with 2-3 people dead.  In previous seasons, a team could take the Inhib turret and inhib itself at around 25-30 minutes.  Now it seems at 25 minutes that having 3 people dead on either team means the end of the game.  Granted this is the old TSM strategy where you group and wait for the enemy to make that 1 mistake and win the game off of that, but this seems to be happening at the 25 minute mark and not the 35 minute mark like it used to do.

The weaker turrets also make the games seem really snowball much to quickly.  If I'm playing top lane and I get ganked by the jungler at level 3, the game almost feels lost already.  Another problem with the junglers is, the massive amount of movement speed that they get.  With Swifties and Mobies going to go to boots for a majority of junglers, along with Dead Man's Plate (love this item BTW) ZZ Rot Portal (RIP), junglers have a massive amount of movement speed.  This means that they are able to run around the map and take towers rather quickly.  This isn't necessarily the problem, the problem is how many turrets they can take in such a short amount of time.

This also negatively affects late game scaling champions, specifically Nasus and Viegar.  I now feel like there is no good scenario where I would pick either of those champions.

The way that towers are now, makes dragons 2 and 4 almost seem worthless.  Back when Dragon used to give global gold, it was an objective that was fought even right at 2:30 when it spawned, even in competitive play.  Now we're seeing dragon being taken at 12 minutes, and half the time it's because, well, there was no other objectives to take.

And finally if we look at Rift Harold, the whole idea of this buff is to give that person a distinct advantage while having the buff.  In top lane especially, this means pushing your wave to the turret until it dies, and more times than not, I've seen at least one tower being taken after Rift Harold was taken.

I understand that you guys wanted to push faster games, and to be honest, it's actually kind of nice.  One thing about MOBA's like League or HoTS or Dota 2 is that you can't just leave the game and que right back up again like you can in COD or Rocket League.  So I appreciate the shorter games.  The problem is, turrets seem to be so fragile, that one mistake at 18 minutes can almost cost you the game.

We bundle these class focused updates into patches for a couple of reasons in particular:

* Working on multiple members of a class at once means we've got a number of designers all tackling similar problems at the same time. That means they're able to build up frameworks to work within together (e.g. what tools should a juggernaut have, which strategic spaces would it be healthy to shift marksmen into to differentiate them etc). That leads to a more productive way of working an helps avoid kit overlap (one of the biggest things we're trying to fix) as we map out space for multiple champions at once.
* Doing batches of a class together mean we can then make more comprehensive item changes in conjunction with the champion updates that support and synergize with the kits. As above developing an understanding of the classes strengths and weaknesses as a group then also helps a lot with understanding itemization needs and restrictions.

So would Aatrox/Xin/Irelia/Kayle/Jax be considered as a Sub-Class that could get updates in the future?

Aatrox, Xin, Irelia are champs we classify as diving fighters. If we were doing a diver update (divers are one of the groups we'd like to get to at some point) we'd definitely want to work on Aatrox, suspect we'd probably do at least some lighter work on Xin and Irelia. 

Jax we see as a hybrid of diving fighter and light fighter (like Yi, Trynd, Yasuo etc).

Kayle's a weird hybrid that doesn't fit any of our sub class definitions well. That's ok, they're there as ways to assess champions, not necessarily rigid requirements (Singed is another good example of a hard to categorize champ, with elements of juggerant, initiator tank and his own stuff rolled together).

What would you categorize Azir as? He seems like a mage, but somehow to me he looks much more similar to GP than anyone else in the game. I get the feeling that post update zyra may also seem very similar to both of them.

I think that classifying something as mage or marksman may be in error, classification on playstyle rather than on itemization. From my perspective Jhin for example would be a mage, and Azir a marksman.
Azir doesn't fit any of our control sub classes particular well, though he's got elements of both marksmen and control mages (champs like Heimer and Anivia).

On the topic of Ryze, can you explain why you're so concerned with him? I know win rates aren't everything, but the fact remains he only has about a 43% win rate top (his best role). Mid he is doing even worse.

Ryze has been a problem champion frankly forever, starting in beta, where he'd kill you with just his ult at level 6 and continuing through the years. Shifting him to a mana scaling mage with a closer focus and sustained damage pattern a number of years back helped a lot in terms of finding him an identity. Making him healthy within it's been tougher though, in particular finding ways to make him balanceable for a sufficient range of skill levels. His rework last year didn't address his issues overall unfortunately, improving some things but introducing some other problems in the process. As a result he's still been in a state where he's effectively a terrible choice for people who haven't played him a lot, while being very overpowered and nerf worthy in the hands of experienced Ryze players.
